subNodes.conversationText: root
"I am the beast beneath the house of murder."
"You must know much about these woods, spirit. I'm looking for a murderer."

The wolf inhaled long and deep through its nostrils.

"Nothing lives that does not kill another For its life."
[Continue.]
The wolf pondered <FirstName>. Pharaoh had retreated to some corner of the cave, and Knott was nowhere to be seen. The young witch felt alone.
[Continue.]

"A foretaste, then, of your unripened flesh --
No harm to you, I swear. A little lick
So I can taste the question you don't know
To ask. Give me your hand."
<FirstName> offered the wolf <his/her> hand.
A tongue emerged from the beast's tusky mouth and slid over <FirstName>'s outstretched hand.
[Continue.]

<He/She> felt the spirit run through <him/her>. Freed from its roots in the earth, it trotted through the meadows and woods of <his/her> memory. It entered the witches' house and sniffed at Nnenne's grave. It galloped back into <FirstName>'s adolescence, circled the feet of <his/her> parents, leapt into <his/her> cradle...
[Continue.]
It sank onto <his/her> infant form and put its snout against <his/her> left ear. Then it opened its jaws.
[Continue.]
Between the teeth and tusks was a young man. He had a cup in one hand and a sword in the other. He stood on a hill. There was something sad but unjust about his beauty.
[Continue.]
The vision faded.
[Continue.]
"Wee Malkin was his name," said the wolf. "Tell the witch You know it."
[Continue.]
Before <FirstName> could respond, <he/she> found <him/her>self outside.

actions.a_parameter_1: THE THREE SPIRITS has been added to journal.

subNodes.conversationText: [Continue.]
Between the teeth and tusks stood Middle One and Eldest Lady. They held out the same cup <FirstName> had seen in <his/her> first vision, and Wee Malkin took it. It was empty.
[Continue.]
"You have drunk up all our wisdom, Wee Malkin. The spirits have more. Go to them. Find out what they can give you. Come back, share it."
[Continue.]
Wee Malkin walked into the wolf's gullet.
[Continue.]
"Come back? Share it?" asked Middle One, after he had gone.
[Continue.]
"Middle One, Middle One... Our brother wouldn't share it if he could."
[Continue.]
The vision faded.
[Continue.]
"Find Wee Malkin," the wolf said. "The woodcutter's son knows the way."
Continue
Before <FirstName> could respond, <he/she> found <him/her>self outside.
"I am no fool, spirit."
"Fools learn things the wise do not."
<FirstName> offered the wolf <his/her> hand.
"Then consider me too wise for your lessons."

The wolf shook its humongous head, unsetting the earth. Dust, rocks, and debris fell into the chamber.

"Then go."
[Continue.]
Before <FirstName> could respond, <he/she> found <him/her>self outside.
[End.]
The young witch trembled and said nothing.
"Did you come here with no boon to beg?"
[Continue.]
The young witch tried to flee from the cave.

"Tarry, tarry. You are not for me --
Yet."
"You must know much about these woods, oh spirit. I seek a murderer who lives here."
The young witch trembled and said nothing.
[Continue.]
"I eat corruption's leavings, form's old skins."
[Continue.]

"The leaves that moulder in the blood-soil swill,
The sticky hair that gristle leaves behind --
I chew it all. Why do things that breathe
Resist?"
[Continue.]

"Famine's just a word to me --
I am as hungry as the leanest wolf,
But the pantry keeps me overfed."
"You must know much about these woods, oh spirit. I seek a murderer who lives here."
The young witch trembled and said nothing.
The young witch tried to flee from the cave.
"Another spirit. Tell me of Wee Malkin."
"Another spirit. Tell me of Wee Malkin."
The wolf pondered <FirstName>. Pharaoh had retreated to some corner of the cave, and Knott was nowhere to be seen. The young witch felt alone.

Some force lifted <FirstName> into the air. <He/She> stared at the creature before <him/her>. It had the head of an enormous wolf. Its eyes glowed red, and it had tusks as well as jaws. The tip of a sword protruded from its forehead like a unicorn's horn. Bent saplings and thousands of roots sprouted from its fur.
[Continue.]
It spoke, and a few yellow leaves fell.
[Continue.]
"I am the beast beneath the house of murder."
